ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Memorization, being able to look back on past readings, grammar analysis. Obviously we learned how to read hieroglyphs but I think more importantly, I learned how to take good notes to look back on when I need them!
I learned how to translate different Egyptian texts, and how to analyze the grammatical structure of passages.

After finishing the remaining grammar, we were able to apply our understanding and explore a diversity of texts (wisdom literature, narrative, letter, stela). Insight into Middle Egyptian culture and philosophy accompanied our readings. This class provided good practice for reading Middle Egyptian

I learned how to reach Middle Egyptian Hieroglyphic! How amazing is that! The Egyptian language is very interesting and I have loved learning it. By this semester, you learn pretty much all you need to actually start reading texts and it's so much fun. The language is very interesting and the translation assignments felt more like solving puzzles sometimes than school work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that it's awesome that we get to read real texts in this class. I think weaknesses might be that the real texts are a little bit difficult at first, but not a big deal.

Strengths: we were able to practice transliterating and translating texts, which was a good way to strengthen our grasp on the language. Professor Chantrain is very accommodating and wants her students to learn. Weakness: The difficulty level of texts that we read was high especially coming out of a break. I wish we would have started off with easier texts before moving on to more difficult ones.

Professor Chantrain was absolutely amazing! She was always encouraging and supportive, presenting the material to make sure we understood it and reviewing as needed. Her dedication to our learning was forefront and you could feel how much she cares about her students and loves the subject. The focus of the class on the application of the grammar to reading various texts really helped me practice and feel confident in my translation skills. I especially liked following along with Sinuhe and the discussions we had about its larger themes.

I do not see much that can be improved. This class was exceptional.
No weaknesses at all! The professor is amazing and the course structure was very good.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was good because it required everyone to participate, something which a lot of zoom classes have failed to do.
great format for an online class

The live lectures were engaging and kept everyone participating by having each student explain their analysis of at least one line from the homework. Another useful feature was the breakout rooms in which we formed groups of four to work on translating the text we were seeing in class. Being able to then return to the main session to go over what we worked on was a useful exercise.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course. Although the language itself isn't easy, professor chantrain made the class engaging and manageable. Also, the workload compared to other language credits is much less.

Most definitely! You will get much more practice with applying all the individual grammar topics by reading texts in this class. Additionally, there are many interesting discussions that evolve from these longer pieces that give insight into Middle Egyptian culture. It was super fun and rewarding. Professor Chantrain was also the best! She brightened up the early mornings and was extremely passionate about Egyptian. I thoroughly enjoyed the extra nuances she would address and attention to which we gave each particular construction. This class is awesome!
Hands-down yes. The language is awesome and the culture is very interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
